ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Linear algebra! Matrix stuff and decompositions and inverses and eigenvalues a little
I built a solid background in linear algebra, including topics like eigenvectors/values, subspaces, span/bases, orthogonality, matrix multiplication, etc.
Linear Algebra
I learned the basics of linear algebra.

The class taught a basic overview of linear algebra (matrices, Gauss elimination, vector spaces, bases, orthogonality, projection, determinants, eigenvectors). Occasionally there were a few "applications" (e.g., the least squares method, the triangle inequality) but they often felt like digressions and were rarely presented as important parts of the material. As someone who had taken a linear algebra class in high school but took this because I felt I might not have gotten all the content, I was surprised that this course didn't actually go much more in depth. That said, I think I became more proficient and confident at working with matrices, and especially at understanding many concepts visually -- though a lot of this development happened not because it was taught in the class, but because I looked up material online in order to understand what was being taught in the class.
The basics of linear algebra! How to solve a system of equations, the use of null space, orthogonality, determinants, eigenvalues/vectors, and more.
Ability to perform rote computations

Like many other reviews of this course suggest, the courses name is a misnomer. We were given the tools to understand the functionality of linear algebra in many of its applications but were only introduced to very few of these applications. In general, we learned matrix arithmetic, the properties of matrices, and many ways to solve systems of multiple equations.
A lot of knowledge regarding linear algebra and how to use it to simplify calculations.
This course is worth almost nothing. Covers basic linear algebra topics yes, but youre better off just buying a textbook and reading it yourself.
High level math at yale
Matrix operations, solving linear equations
I learned all the fundamentals of linear algebra, including various methods of solving systems of equations, matrix manipulation, and vector/matrix subspaces.
I learned about linear algebra.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Slightly chaotic with organization but wonderful to learn with prof 
More direction would be great and explanation of purpose. I don't think there needs to be so much rigorous proving of concepts we trust you in an applications course and it distracts from the content sometimes
The class is not very organized. The was no notes posted and no solutions to set problems, and it was hard to get feedback or help

This course is honestly a really great overview of linear algebra. I came out of it feeling as comfortable as I can feel I think in something like linear algebra. The strengths were certainly the professor (Mathias is great) and the psets (which I thought were quite well done and decent length). I would say this class could be improved with more discussion of real-world applications throughout the lectures. It also would've been great if Mathias posted the answers to the psets when they were done so we could study them.
There should be more mathematical examples and applications of concepts shown in class rather than abstract proofs.
I think the course could have a better textbook. I am not a big fan of the one we used.

Strengths: Communication was very good -- especially helpful was the use of the Ed Discussion platform that allowed students to ask questions in an online forum and receive answers quickly from peers and teachers. Homework expectations were clear and there were ample review sessions. I think the overall mix of computation and theory was about right -- not just rote work, but not strict proofs either -- even if the teaching was not ideal in other respects. Weaknesses: It might just be inevitable, but engagement with the class was very poor. Often, not a single student would answer the professor's questions. Additionally, lectures could become hard to follow because examples, sub-cases, proofs, and new topics were not always clearly distinguished from each other (in speaking or on the blackboard). More references to the bigger picture and how everything fits together (e.g., "this is just another way of expressing...") would vastly improve the clarity of the teaching.
Lectures were a little boring and hard to follow. The majority of the time I had to read the textbook to understand what was being taught. But this could be because the class was at 9 am idk.
More visual depictions of the topics we learn about, better contextualization

Strengths: Prof Schacht is a very understanding and reasonable professor, problem sets & exams were fair and representative of the concepts we learned. Weaknesses: It would have been helpful to see more example problems in class, I also personally did not learn well from the textbook we used

Professor Schacht spent the time to derive many of the rules and concepts we used which gave us a great background for each topic, but also made pacing feel slow at times and caused us to not cover some of the topics we planned to review at the end of the semester. That being said I definitely do not think that a thorough understanding of the concepts should be compromised to add new topics, so I would say this course was great as is.

This course was an abysmal introduction to linear algebra and should be redesigned entirely. Lectures were unclear and unhelpful, and little to no syllabus organized the topics covered. The textbook was closely followed, though it would have been great if another book was chosen (even Gilbert Strangs other textbook- I read all of both and prefer that one as a reference). This book has great intuitive explanations of the way many concepts in linear algebra overlap and interact, but has little structure and reads as a brick wall of prose without any theorems or key points highlighted. Unfortunately the intuitive (albeit dense) explanations of the textbook were not presented in lecture. To make matters worse, assignments and exams focused on computation, rather than understanding of the material. Its here where I start to wonder the reason for the existence of this course. We live in the 21st century. Computers were *literally* designed to deal with busywork matrix operations. If one isnt to take MATH 225 to explore the formal foundations of the field of linear algebra, the alternative should be a course that teaches the intuitions with real world applications. Yes, techniques such as gaussian elimination, factorization techniques, and inverse calculation should all be learned by hand initially. More important, however would be to actually explain when these techniques are necessary, and teach how one would use them in life. The concepts of linear algebra overlap and interact so beautifully, and it was a shame that this beauty was lost in a sea of pedantic busywork on every pset. Make me calculate a 4x4 inverse once on a pset and once on an exam, sure. Then teach me how to do it in matlab, and make me use matlab to solve an actual conceptually nontrivial problem. Meanwhile, for a course allegedly focused on applications there were no applications to be seen. I feel like the course not only failed to teach how linear algebra works, but also why anyone should care to learn it. I feel like I thought myself from the book and would have been better off learning entirely on my own.
The lectures were horrible

Strengths: reasonable workload, concepts were well explained, exams very reasonable, peer tutors were a great help
Weaknesses: some concepts could have been explained better with more examples

This course provides an excellent foundation in linear algebra. You learn all the mechanics of solving problems, while also getting intuitive explanations without needing to rigorous proofs. I cant say there are any glaring weaknesses.
The class taught us lots of proofs and definitions but didnt have a lot of practical applications or examples. I often had to look things up from other universities to understand the content.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Sure it's cool to learn math that is not calculus and has so many implications in different fields!

I would if you wish to learn linear algebra! I took it for future ML courses and definitely feel a lot better about going into those courses after this class. I think this is a great course to take if you don't want to do a lot of theory/proofs (which is what I hear 225 is) and honestly it's a super reasonable math class.
No, the level of engagement in this course was low. Lectures lacked application of mathematical concepts to real-world.
I would only recommend this course to a student who doesn't want to take Math 225 (because it is too difficult), or if it is required for them. I found that the course wasn't too engaging.

This course wasn't terrible -- it definitely wasn't one of those math courses that make you wonder how it's still taught so badly at Yale. Rather, this was a broadly *meh* course. You have to watch out against getting lost in some of the lectures, but if you have a solid understanding of your metaphorical location in the domain of linear algebra at any given time, the class is pretty straightforward and not a pain to do by any means. I'm not sure if you'll necessarily come out of it knowing how to "apply linear algebra" to other subjects, but you'll at least know what people are talking about when they mention determinants or transformations.

ehh maybe if you really need it for a major requirement. If not then maybe look elsewhere or watch Khan academy if you really want to learn about linear algebra because that's how I got ready for the exams.
No, there's a disconnect between the contextual understanding tested on exams and the substance of the lectures

If for some reason you need it for some prereq or really want to just do applications, then yes. If youre more interested in math and want to take a Lin Alg course (less applications, more proof-based), Ive heard better things about MATH 225.

I would definitely recommend this to any student interested in higher level ecology or statistics. This is a great course taken alongside stats 238, since this course provides the reasoning for the statistical procedures that we did not have time to delve into over the course of 238. The more quantitative side of ecology uses what weve learned for analyses of succession and life tables, so this class was a great way to clarify the possibilities in these realms.

No. If you have the time and interest, take MATH 225. This course is awfully taught and should be redesigned entirely to actually focus on applications with computer calculation (MATLAB), and provide intuitive explanation of the topics involved. Currently, it is mostly busywork calculations and fails to connect many of the key concepts that are so beautiful in linear algebra. Of course, it is a requirement, and many arent ready or simply dont want the rigorous and abstract presentation of MATH 225. In that case, youre screwed. Find yourself a good textbook and buckle up. Fortunately, the p-sets and exams are pretty easy if you learn the material from any competent source (not class).
Yes
Yes, this math class was not too difficult and I learned some interesting applications.
Definitely recommend this course if youre a STEM major who wants to understand how to use linear algebra but doesnt care to do formal proofs.
No. If you dont have to take it, dont. It is not fun
